newsitem.title: CHINA: Difficult for Deng to visit HK - vice mayor.
newsitem.headline: Difficult for Deng to visit HK - vice mayor.

text.p: China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping is in good health, but it will be difficult for him to visit Hong Kong in mid-1997 when the British colony reverts to Chinese rule, Beijing Vice-Mayor Zhang Baifa said on Monday.
"To my knowledge, it is very good," Zhang told reporters when asked about Deng's health at a Christmas reception for diplomats and foreign journalists in Beijing.
Zhang, who is believed to be close to the Deng family, said he had not visited the patriarch recently but that Deng was in Beijing.
Asked if Deng would visit Hong Kong for the handover ceremony, Zhang said: "He said it himself -- he will go to Hong Kong even it means in a wheelchair."
But Zhang added: "It would be difficult for him to go now. It would be disastrous for an old man in his 90s to catch cold. Catching cold would be a serious illness."

Deng, 92, no longer holds any office but remains highly influential. He has not been seen in public since early 1994. His health is a matter of intense speculation in China and neighbouring countries because his death is expected to trigger a scramble for power among those eager to succeed him.
